titleStmt.title: A man of gigantic
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Words and ideas that appear in this manuscript are similar to segments of the 1855 poem that was eventually titled "Song of Myself." Edward Grier also connects the image of the heroic male and the "flowing grandeur of a man" to the poems that make up the 1855 Leaves (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 1:178). The date of this manuscript is therefore probably before or early in 1855.

note.p: Words and ideas from this manuscript may have contributed to the poem that was eventually titled "Song of Myself." The words, struck through in this manuscript, "has the knowledge of the perfect equanimity," are similar to the line "Knowing the perfect fitness and equanimity of things, while they discuss I am silent" (1855, p. 14). The segment "tender to children and old people and women—indulging most the stupid the sinful and the vulgar—because them the world is most down upon—" is similar to the following lines from what would become section 24 of "Song of Myself": "And of the rights of them the others are down upon, / Of the trivial and flat and foolish and despised" (1855, p. 29).

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt

bibl.note: Another prose manuscript written on the back of this leaf relates to the 1855 preface to Leaves of Grass.
Transcribed from digital images of the original.

ab.hi: Picture of the most flowing grandeur of a man

body.ab: When a man joined to his great power, and wealth and strength, has the knowledge of the perfect equanimity and
body.p: A man of gigantic, stature, supple, healthy, accomplished, powerful, and resistless, is a great man—But when such an one a man with all that is not trapped into any partiality or sh—when he strikes the eternal balance between the eternal average of the developed and the undeveloped—when he isgoes on the square with those who have not yet climbed as high as he—tender to children and old people and women—indulging most the stupid the sinful and the vulgar—because them the world is most down upon—
